items.title: Ill Prepared for Combat, Volunteers Die in Battles Far From Home
items.description: Many of the fighters for Ukraine’s western territorial defense units were assigned benign tasks away from the fighting when they first joined. Then they were called to the front to fight.
items.author: Megan Specia

items.title: In Pakistan, a Leader in Trans Rights, Reality Is Slower to Change Than Law
items.description: Four years after the country became one of the few to protect transgender people’s rights in statute, violence against them has surged and discrimination remains common.
items.author: Zia ur-Rehman

items.title: From the Early Morning Sky, Shards of Hot Metal
items.description: Ukrainians reacted in fury to a Russian missile strike near Odesa, the latest in a string of attacks on civilian targets.
items.author: Roger Cohen

items.title: His Union Went on Strike. His Interviews Went Viral.
items.description: At a time of rampant inflation and wage stagnation, Mick Lynch, the force behind Britain’s largest railway strikes in three decades, has found success that has surprised even his colleagues.
items.author: Saskia Solomon

items.title: Live Updates: Grinding Ahead in Ukraine’s East, Russia Struggles in South
items.description: Ukrainian soldiers have been chipping away at Russian frontline positions in the southern part of the country.
items.author: The New York Times

items.title: Brittney Griner’s Detention in Moscow Is Latest in Hostage Diplomacy
items.description: The United States believes the charges against the basketball star are spurious and tied to American support of Ukraine.
items.author: Max Fisher

items.title: Japan Swelters Through a Punishing Heat Wave
items.description: Temperatures in Tokyo surpassed 95 degrees for the eighth straight day on Saturday, a streak seen only once before since 1875.
items.author: Hisako Ueno and Karan Deep Singh

items.title: More Mexicans Are Migrating to the U.S. After a Decade-Long Drop
items.description: The death of at least 53 migrants in Texas, more than half of whom were from Mexico, is testing U.S. efforts to enlist Mexico in deterring migration.
items.author: Oscar Lopez and Maria Abi-Habib

items.title: Russia Repeatedly Strikes Ukraine’s Civilians. There’s Always an Excuse.
items.description: The Kremlin’s explanations have sometimes satisfied the Russian people, but they fall apart under closer scrutiny abroad.
items.author: Daniel Victor and Ivan Nechepurenko

items.title: ‘Long Live the Theater’: Mariupol’s Drama Company to Perform Again
items.description: Thirteen members of the Mariupol Drama Theater have reconvened in western Ukraine where they are rehearsing a new play about a Ukrainian dissident who died in a Russian prison camp in the 1980s.
items.author: Megan Specia

items.title: Venice Will Require Tourists to Register and Pay Entry Fee
items.description: City officials are introducing a new fee to visit Venice and its islands, a move, they hope, will limit tourists.
items.author: Elisabetta Povoledo

items.title: Tunisia’s President, Kais Saied, Proposes New Constitution
items.description: The proposal, which will be put to a national referendum on July 25, would enshrine the significant steps he has taken over the past year to dismantle the North African nation’s young democracy.
items.author: Vivian Yee

items.title: Why Is There So Much Turmoil in Eastern Congo?
items.description: More than 120 militia groups are wreaking terror in the Democratic Republic of Congo, which now accuses neighboring Rwanda of backing one particularly violent group.
items.author: Ruth Maclean and Abdi Latif Dahir

items.title: Labeled a ‘Challenge’ by NATO, China Signals Its Own Hard-Line Worldview
items.description: The alliance’s forceful declaration in its mission statement reinforced Beijing’s belief that hostile powers are bent on hobbling the country’s ascent.
items.author: Amy Qin and Austin Ramzy

items.title: Ukrainian Students Are Hopeful and Defiant as They Graduate Amid War
items.description: For these students, this coming-of-age moment amid the war is especially poignant.
items.author: Megan Specia and Emile Ducke

items.title: Searching for Gold, Miners Discover a Frozen Baby Mammoth
items.description: Experts believe that the woolly mammoth, unearthed in the Klondike gold fields of the Yukon of Canada, had been preserved in the frozen ground for more than 30,000 years.
items.author: Christine Chung

items.title: Ukraine accuses Russia of dropping white phosphorous on Snake Island after its retreat.
items.description: Some observers speculated that the strike was a move to destroy equipment that Russia had abandoned on the island and to complicate any future Ukrainian presence there.
items.author: Valerie Hopkins

items.title: A Guide to Fourth of July Weekend
items.description: Recommendations for a summer holiday — movies, podcasts, “Stranger Things” and cobbler.
items.author: Melissa Kirsch

items.title: Ukraine dreams of rebuilding the world’s largest airplane. Can Richard Branson help?
items.description: A Virgin Group spokesperson said the effort would turn to finding ways the international community could support the project.
items.author: Jeffrey Gettleman

items.title: Japan’s Secret to Taming the Coronavirus: Peer Pressure
items.description: The country has never mandated masks or vaccinations, but it’s evaded the worst of Covid, thanks to a fear of public shaming and the “self restraint police.”
items.author: Motoko Rich and Ben Dooley

items.title: Iran Earthquake Kills at Least 5, State Media Says
items.description: Iran’s state news agency said the quake, which did extensive damage to a village, was followed by two more.
items.author: Reuters

items.title: At Comedy Shows in Lviv, Crowds Look for Humor Amid a Deadly War
items.description: At the Cultural Defense shows in Lviv, comedians and audiences look for humor amid a deadly conflict. Don’t mind the air raid alarms.
items.author: David Segal

items.title: Biden Administration Offers an Offshore Drilling Plan. Likely Backers: Very Few.
items.description: The five-year plan for America’s coastal waters, required by law, risks angering both the fossil fuel industry and environmentalists.
items.author: Lisa Friedman

items.title: Brittney Griner, Women’s Basketball Star, Goes on Trial in Russia
items.description: The American basketball star Brittney Griner has endured months in a Russian prison and the threat of years more, a wartime bargaining chip between Moscow and Washington.
items.author: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

items.title: Did the ‘Freedom Convoy’ Change the Meaning of Canada’s Flag?
items.description: On Canada Day, some citizens were wary of raising the national flag, now also associated with weeks of protests against pandemic mandates.
items.author: Vjosa Isai

items.title: California Requires Plastics Makers to Foot the Bill for Recycling
items.description: The landmark legislation also restricts single-use plastics. Because California’s economy is so big, experts say, the law could have far-reaching effects.
items.author: Winston Choi-Schagrin

items.title: With Climate Agenda Stalled at Home, Biden Still Hopes to Lead Abroad
items.description: The United States has demonstrated international leadership on climate change in the past, but recent setbacks are presenting new challenges for President Biden.
items.author: David Gelles

items.title: Will There Be Enough Monkeypox Vaccine?
items.description: A factory making Jynneos, the safest vaccine, has been closed since August, threatening global supplies as the virus spreads.
items.author: Apoorva Mandavilli

items.title: Denmark’s Leader Apologizes for Botched Pandemic Mink Cull
items.description: The comments by Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen came after a report called the government’s decision in 2020 to kill some 17 million mink over coronavirus fears illegal.
items.author: Emma Bubola, Isabella Kwai and Jasmina Nielsen

items.title: Benin Bronzes Returned to Nigeria from Germany
items.description: Two of the renowned artifacts were given back to Nigeria on Friday, and Germany intends to give the African country ownership of some 1,100 more.
items.author: Alex Marshall

items.title: New Zealand Designates Proud Boys a Terrorist Group
items.description: The far-right Proud Boys are not known to operate in the country, but the designation makes it illegal for New Zealanders to support them.
items.author: Daniel Victor

items.title: Tropical Storm Bonnie Makes Landfall in Nicaragua
items.description: Bonnie lashed Nicaragua and Costa Rica late Friday after becoming the second named storm of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.
items.author: The New York Times

items.title: The Kremlin rejects the suggestion that Griner’s case is politically motivated.
items.author: Ivan Nechepurenko

items.title: A Look Inside the Lockup Where Brittney Griner Has Been Held
items.description: At least one other well-known foreigner has spent time there: Naama Issachar, the Israeli-American arrested in April 2019 when the Russian police said they had found marijuana in her luggage.
items.author: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

items.title: The Court vs. the Climate
items.description: The Supreme Court seems unconcerned with climate change.
items.author: David Leonhardt

items.title: Landslide in India Buries Dozens, Killing at Least 25
items.description: Days of heavy rain had loosened the soil. India and neighboring Bangladesh have had record rainfall and severe flooding in the past two months.
items.author: Karan Deep Singh

items.title: Xi Jinping Tells a Muted Hong Kong That Political Power Is for Patriots
items.description: The Chinese leader’s first visit to the former British colony since a sweeping crackdown was a declaration of victory, an assertion of power and a warning to critics.
items.author: Austin Ramzy and Vivian Wang

items.title: ‘Mango Man’ Is the Fruit’s Foremost Poet, Philosopher, Fan and Scientist
items.description: With 300 types of mangos to his horticultural credit, Kaleem Ullah Khan is quick to tell anyone in India and beyond about the infinite potential of the fruit and its tree, including as medicine.
items.author: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar

items.title: Yair Lapid, Israel’s New Prime Minister, Played the Long Game to Power
items.description: Once mocked for his inexperience and perceived arrogance, Israel’s caretaker premier taught voters a lesson in political maturity and humility.
items.author: Isabel Kershner

items.title: As Federal Climate-Fighting Tools Are Taken Away, Cities and States Step Up
items.description: Across the country, local governments are accelerating their efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions, in some cases bridging partisan divides. Their role will become increasingly important.
items.author: Maggie Astor

items.title: What to Know About Flight Delays and Cancellations This Summer
items.description: Going into the Fourth of July weekend, with nearly 13 million people expected to fly on U.S. carriers, we look at the numbers behind the delays and cancellations and see what lessons can be learned.
items.author: Heather Murphy

items.title: Pictures of Brittney Griner in Custody Offer Few Clues to Her Well-Being
items.description: Images of the W.N.B.A. star released since her arrest in an airport near Moscow on Feb. 17 have been scrutinized for clues about her mental and physical health.
items.author: Maham Javaid

items.title: Russia hints at linking Griner’s case to Viktor Bout, a Russian known as the ‘Merchant of Death.’
items.author: Michael Crowley

items.title: Climate Protesters in Australia Face Harsh New Penalties
items.description: As of April, people in New South Wales who disrupt business activities can face up to two years in prison. Some climate activists say this law is aimed at them.
items.author: Yan Zhuang

items.title: North Korea Suggests ‘Alien Things’ From South Brought Covid
items.description: Airborne propaganda leaflets sent by activists across the border have long angered the regime, which pointed to them as the likely culprit in the country’s recent outbreak.
items.author: Choe Sang-Hun

items.title: Your Friday Briefing
items.description: A major climate-related court ruling.
items.author: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg

items.title: Missile Strikes on Ukraine Kill at Least 21 Near Odesa
items.description: The strikes hit a residential tower and a recreational center in a coastal town southwest of the Black Sea port city of Odesa.
items.author: Eduardo Medina and Victoria Kim

items.title: ‘Wearing a Piece of History’: Vintage Clothing Stores Find a Growing Market
items.description: The demand for repurposed clothes is rising in Australia, store owners say, as shoppers look for sustainability and history over fast fashion.
items.author: Manan Luthra

items.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Major U.S. Climate Ruling
items.description: Plus Xi Jinping visits Hong Kong and Ukraine takes back Snake Island.
items.author: Amelia Nierenberg

items.title: Biden Vows to Back Ukraine ‘as Long as It Takes’ Despite Economic Toll
items.description: NATO leaders concluded a summit with new commitments to a united front against Russian aggression, but they face the challenge of persuading their own people that it’s worth the cost.
items.author: Steven Erlanger, Jim Tankersley, Michael D. Shear and Alan Yuhas

items.title: Belgian Court Finds 10 Guilty Over Ties to 2015 Paris Attacks
items.description: The convictions followed the end of a giant trial in the French capital over the same massacre, in which 130 people were killed.
items.author: Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut

items.title: Court Decision Leaves Biden With Few Tools to Combat Climate Change
items.description: A Supreme Court ruling, combined with an energy crunch and intraparty politics, makes it nearly impossible for President Biden to achieve his climate goals.
items.author: Coral Davenport

items.title: Saudi Arabia Bankrolls a Challenge to the PGA
items.description: Saudi Arabia is investing in sporting events, like an upstart golf tour, as part of a yearslong drive to turn the country into a hot spot for business and tourism and to blunt criticism of its human rights record.
items.author: Vivian Yee and Ben Hubbard

items.title: Hong Kong’s Transformation Since Handover
items.description: In the 25 years since the handover to China, life on Queen’s Road, the first thoroughfare built by the British after they seized the territory, has been transformed.
items.author: Hannah Beech and Sergey Ponomarev

items.title: Biden Endorses Ending Filibuster to Codify Abortion Rights
items.description: The president called the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade “destabilizing’’ and said Congress needed to act to codify it into law.
items.author: Michael D. Shear and Jim Tankersley

items.title: To Save Its Honey Industry, Australia Is Killing Bees by the Millions
items.description: Australia is the only major honey-producing country that has so far managed to contain the spread of a mite fatal to bees. That distinction is now in peril.
items.author: Karan Deep Singh

items.title: Missing From Biden’s Europe Trip: An Endgame for War and Cheaper Gas
items.description: The G7 and NATO meetings this week underscored the pressure on Western leaders caused by soaring energy costs resulting from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
items.author: Jim Tankersley and Michael D. Shear

items.title: Marcos Becomes President in the Philippines
items.description: The son of the former dictator used his inauguration speech to discuss the economy and the need to heal a deeply divided country after a polarizing election.
items.author: Jason Gutierrez and Sui-Lee Wee

items.title: A Powerful Court
items.description: In other advanced democracies, the courts are more restrained.
items.author: German Lopez
